content: After years of experience in peacekeeping and peacebuilding operations, analysts emphasize the importance of establishing a secure environment for sustainable peace. Military forces are crucial for initial security, but civilian police (CivPol) are increasingly seen as more suitable for maintaining law and order in post-conflict environments. Over the past decade, international civilian police (CivPol) have gained recognition as more suitable than military forces for law and order tasks. Policymakers are addressing issues with CivPol use and considering improvements to the existing system and building new capabilities. Advocates propose reforms to improve existing CivPol systems and ensure appropriate training for law enforcement personnel in post-conflict missions. Key documents like the Clinton Administration's PDD-71 recommend mechanisms for enhancing CivPol capabilities. The February 2000 Presidential Decision Directive 71 (PDD-71) and the United Nations' August 2000 "Brahimi Panel" report contain recommendations for improving law enforcement aspects of peacekeeping operations, including the creation of a reserve CivPol force. The Bush Administration has started implementing some measures, while the UN is working on implementing the Brahimi Panel recommendations. Advocates recommend creating a reserve CivPol force, diversifying international police forces, and establishing robust civilian response mechanisms to improve law enforcement in post-conflict operations and potentially reduce reliance on U.S. military forces.
